cards.name: Rancor

rulings.text: If the creature this Aura would enchant is an illegal target by the time Rancor tries to resolve, the Aura spell doesn’t resolve. It won’t enter the battlefield, so it won’t be put into a graveyard from the battlefield and its ability won’t trigger.

cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets +2/+0 and has trample.
When Rancor is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, return Rancor to its owner's hand.

cards.flavorText: I am the purifier, the light that clears all shadows. —Seal inscription
cards.name: Seal of Cleansing

rulings.text: This is not modal. If the target changes from an artifact to an enchantment or vice versa, this still destroys it.

cards.text: Sacrifice Seal of Cleansing: Destroy target artifact or enchantment.

cards.flavorText: For dim-witted, thick-skulled genetic mutants, they have pretty good aim. —Sisay
cards.name: Flametongue Kavu

rulings.text: If it enters the battlefield as the only targetable creature, it must target itself.

cards.text: When Flametongue Kavu enters the battlefield, it deals 4 damage to target creature.

cards.name: Blastoderm
cards.text:
Shroud (This creature can't be the target of spells or abilities.)
Fading 3 (This creature enters the battlefield with three fade counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a fade counter from it. If you can't, sacrifice it.)

cards.name: Cabal Therapy

rulings.text: You name the card as Cabal Therapy resolves, not as you cast it. Then the targeted player reveals their hand and discards if appropriate. No player may choose to take actions between you naming the card and the targeted player revealing and discarding.

cards.text:
Choose a nonland card name. Target player reveals their hand and discards all cards with that name.
Flashback—Sacrifice a creature. (You may cast this card from your graveyard for its flashback cost. Then exile it.)

cards.name: Fact or Fiction

rulings.text: You choose which pile to put into your hand.
Each pile may contain from zero to five cards; they don’t have to be split “evenly.”

cards.text: Reveal the top five cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other into your graveyard.

cards.flavorText: Built with neither a way to steer nor a way to stop, the juggernauts were simply aimed at an enemy's best defenses and told to charge.
cards.name: Juggernaut

rulings.text: If Juggernaut can’t attack for any reason (such as being tapped or having come under that player’s control that turn), then it doesn’t attack. If there’s a cost associated with having it attack, its controller isn’t forced to pay that cost, so it doesn’t have to attack in that case either.

cards.text:
Juggernaut attacks each combat if able.
Juggernaut can't be blocked by Walls.

cards.name: Circle of Protection: Red

rulings.text: A source of damage is a permanent, a spell on the stack (including one that creates a permanent), or any object referred to by an object on the stack. A source doesn’t need to be capable of dealing damage to be a legal choice.
Can be used even when there is no damage to prevent. It prevents the next damage (if any) from the source this turn.

cards.text: {1}: The next time a red source of your choice would deal damage to you this turn, prevent that damage.

cards.name: Kird Ape
cards.text: Kird Ape gets +1/+2 as long as you control a Forest.

cards.flavorText: We decide who is worthy of our works. —Gix, Yawgmoth praetor
cards.name: Duress
cards.text: Target opponent reveals their hand. You choose a noncreature, nonland card from it. That player discards that card.

cards.flavorText: It was probably a lousy spell in the first place. —Ertai, wizard adept
cards.name: Counterspell

cards.flavorText: In fire there is the spark of chaos and destruction, the seed of life. In ice there is perfect tranquility, perfect order, and the silence of death.
cards.name: Icy Manipulator

rulings.text: Once a player announces that they’re casting a spell or activating an ability, no player may take other actions until the spell or ability has been paid for. Notably, other players can’t try to tap that player’s permanents to stop them from paying {T} or to stop them from producing enough mana.

cards.text: {1}, {T}: Tap target artifact, creature, or land.
